Home News Weather Sports Entertainment Living Interact Jobs Autos Real Estate Rentals Classifieds Find n Save Home > Around the Block Column > Real-time news Behind Staten Island store, bleach whitewashes the misfit toys
Published: Friday, September 17, 2010, 8:25 AM Updated: Friday, September 17, 2010, 4:01 PM By Jeff Harrell Staten Island Advance Follow 50 Tweet Share close Digg Stumble Upon Fark Reddit Share Email Print Staten Island Advance/Jeff Harrell Dumpster at CVS drugstore in Eltingville runneth over with discarded merchandise that includes toys. STATEN ISLAND, N.Y. -- Somewhere there’s a little girl wishing Santa will bring her a Barbie Peekaboo Place Playset for Christmas.
Just like the brand-new one that was tossed in the Dumpster behind the CVS Pharmacy on Arthur Kill Road in Eltingville Monday afternoon.
Barbie’s Playset wasn’t alone. This Dumpster overflowed with boxes of brand-new toys—toy tableware, an Adventure Play Tent, even brand-new pairs of flip-flop sandals and packets of red, white and blue flag-colored napkins.
There were enough toys to put smiles on several kids’faces, especially kids growing up in a family that can’t afford to smile, let alone shell out a few bucks for Barbie play stuff or a new tent.
Passersby spotted the Dumpster filled with pristine toys in unopened boxes and stopped. Most were Good Samaritans with charity on their minds.
"Christmas is coming, a lot of kids could have them," said Ann Scamardello, who lives behind the store in Armstrong Gardens and wanted to take the discarded toys to a local church.
One strong whiff of bleach quickly put an end to Ann’s charitable impulse.
And one look at the surly CVS employee marching up to the Dumpster and dumping two jugs of Clorox on the discarded toys killed any thoughts I had of grabbing Barbie’s Peekaboo Playset and making some little girl’s day.
Let’s just say we didn’t have a charitable conversation.
"How come you don’t donate this stuff?" I asked.
"They won’t let us," he said, pouring bleach on anything remotely resembling a box with a toy.
"Why not?"
"It’s not up to us."
I’m no expert on the fine art of pouring bleach on toys in a Dumpster, but it looked pretty plain to me that this CVS store manager was taking it upon himself to destroy somebody else’s plan to grab what had been the store’s discarded markdowns and turn them into a charitable cause.
Waste not, want not, was clearly not in this guy’s vocabulary.
"So no one will take it," he said.
Customer service at your service.
"We don’t make those decisions," an assistant manager inside the store said a few minutes later as he stocked frozen food.
"That’s corporate."
Of course it’s corporate. Who else takes perfectly brand-new toys they can’t sell, tosses them in a Dumpster, then soaks them with bleach so some needy kid can’t have them either?
That’s so corporate, Gordon Gekko would be proud.
"He was following policy by insuring the items were not removed from the Dumpster," says CVS Pharmacy’s corporate spokesman Mike DeAngelis.
DeAngelis says people have been known to take toys out of the Dumpster, hurt themselves on the toys, then go back and sue CVS for damages.
In corporate lingo, that’s called "creating a liability"—taking products out of a Dumpster which may or may not be safe.
"If it’s been thrown away, we don’t want anyone to get hurt," DeAngelis says. "We have to protect the liability of the store."
People have also taken toys out of the Dumpster and returned the toys in a scam to get money back, DeAngelis says, although every time I’ve tried to return something without a receipt, I’ve been told to get lost.
"We as a company do make in-kind product donations to charities on a regular basis," DeAngelis adds. "In 2009, we gave products worth a total of $46 million to charity. We have more than 7,000 stores nationwide, many of which have relationships with local non-profits."
In other words, CVS can afford to toss all the Barbie Peekaboo Place Playsets and Adventure Play Tents they want in the Dumpster without batting a corporate eyelash toward little Susie or tiny Timmy.
But what a waste of bleach.
